Lid-driven cavity non stationary problem

This example demonstrates the solution of the classical lid-driven cavity problem for the incompressible Navier–Stokes equations using MMfem.

The cavity is the unit square Ω = (0,1)², with a moving lid on the top boundary.

Problem setup

  • Domain: unit square

  • Boundary conditions: - Top: horizontal velocity (lid) - Other walls: no-slip

  • Discretization: Taylor–Hood elements

  • Solver: Picard / Newton iterations

Python implementation

The complete Python script is shown below.

  1"""
  2Unsteady Lid-Driven Cavity Flow Example
  3
  4This script demonstrates how to solve the time-dependent lid-driven cavity 
  5problem using MMfem. The flow starts from rest and evolves towards the 
  6steady-state solution.
  7
  8Problem setup:
  9    - Domain: [0,1] × [0,1]
 10    - Boundary conditions:
 11        * Top wall (y=1): u = (1, 0) (moving lid)
 12        * Other walls: u = (0, 0) (no-slip)
 13    - Initial condition: u = (0, 0) (flow at rest)
 14    - Reynolds number: Re = UL/ν = 100 (ν = 0.01)
 15
 16This demonstrates the transient dynamics of the classic benchmark problem.
 17"""
 18from ngsolve import CF, GridFunction, VTKOutput
 19from mmfem import (
 20    rectangle_mesh, taylor_hood,
 21    time_stepping_semiimplicit, time_stepping_implicit,
 22    export_time_series
 23)
 24from mmfem.formulations import stokes_problem
 25import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 26import numpy as np
 27
 28
 29def main():
 30    """Run the unsteady lid-driven cavity simulation."""
 31    
 32    print("="*70)
 33    print("UNSTEADY LID-DRIVEN CAVITY FLOW SIMULATION")
 34    print("="*70)
 35    
 36    # Problem parameters
 37    viscosity = 0.001   # Kinematic viscosity (Re = 1000)
 38    h = 0.05           # Mesh size
 39    dt = 0.01          # Time step
 40    T_final = 10.0      # Final time
 41    
 42    print(f"\nProblem Parameters:")
 43    print(f"  Viscosity (ν): {viscosity}")
 44    print(f"  Reynolds number: {1.0 / viscosity}")
 45    print(f"  Mesh size: {h}")
 46    print(f"  Time step (Δt): {dt}")
 47    print(f"  Final time: {T_final}")
 48    print(f"  Number of time steps: {int(T_final / dt)}")
 49    
 50    # Step 1: Create mesh
 51    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 52    print("Step 1: Generating mesh...")
 53    mesh = rectangle_mesh(0, 1, 0, 1, h=h)
 54    print(f"  Number of elements: {mesh.ne}")
 55    print(f"  Number of vertices: {mesh.nv}")
 56    
 57    # Step 2: Define finite element space
 58    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 59    print("Step 2: Setting up finite element space...")
 60    X = taylor_hood(mesh, "left|right|bottom|top")
 61    print(f"  Total DOFs: {X.ndof}")
 62    print(f"  Velocity DOFs: {X.components[0].ndof}")
 63    print(f"  Pressure DOFs: {X.components[1].ndof}")
 64    
 65    # Step 3: Define boundary conditions
 66    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 67    print("Step 3: Defining boundary conditions...")
 68    u_bc = CF((1, 0))  # Moving lid
 69    print(f"  Dirichlet BC on 'top': u = (1, 0)")
 70    print(f"  No-slip BC on other walls: u = (0, 0)")
 71    
 72    # Step 4: Set initial condition
 73    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 74    print("Step 4: Setting initial condition...")
 75    print("  Computing Stokes solution as initial condition...")
 76    
 77    # Use Stokes solution as initial condition
 78    stokes_sol = stokes_problem(mesh, X, "top", u_bc, viscosity)
 79    u0 = stokes_sol.components[0]
 80    
 81    print(f"  Initial condition ready")
 82    
 83    # Step 5: Time stepping
 84    print("\n" + "-"*70)
 85    print("Step 5: Time stepping simulation...")
 86    print("\nChoose time stepping method:")
 87    print("  1. Semi-implicit (fast, requires small time step)")
 88    print("  2. Fully implicit (stable, allows larger time step)")
 89    
 90    choice = input("Enter choice (1 or 2, default=1): ").strip() or "1"
 91    
 92    # Storage for kinetic energy
 93    kinetic_energies = []
 94    
 95    def save_energy(time, timestep, solution):
 96        """Callback to compute and save kinetic energy."""
 97        from ngsolve import Integrate, InnerProduct
 98        velocity = solution.components[0]
 99        KE = 0.5 * Integrate(InnerProduct(velocity, velocity), mesh)
100        kinetic_energies.append((time, KE))
101    
102    if choice == "1":
103        print("\nRunning semi-implicit time stepping...")
104        solutions, times = time_stepping_semiimplicit(
105            mesh=mesh,
106            fespace=X,
107            initial_velocity=u0,
108            dirichlet_boundaries="top",
109            velocity_bc=u_bc,
110            dt=dt,
111            T_final=T_final,
112            viscosity=viscosity,
113            convection_form="standard",
114            save_frequency=10,  # Save every 10 steps
115            verbose=True,
116            callback=save_energy
117        )
118    else:
119        print("\nRunning fully implicit time stepping...")
120        solutions, times = time_stepping_implicit(
121            mesh=mesh,
122            fespace=X,
123            initial_velocity=u0,
124            dirichlet_boundaries="top",
125            velocity_bc=u_bc,
126            dt=0.05,  # Can use larger time step
127            T_final=T_final,
128            viscosity=viscosity,
129            method='picard',
130            tolerance=1e-8,
131            max_nonlinear_iter=20,
132            save_frequency=5,  # Save every 5 steps
133            verbose=True,
134            callback=save_energy
135        )
136    
137    # Step 6: Post-processing
138    print("\n" + "-"*70)
139    print("Step 6: Post-processing and visualization...")
140    
141    # Plot kinetic energy evolution
142    if kinetic_energies:
143        ke_times, ke_values = zip(*kinetic_energies)
144        
145        plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
146        plt.plot(ke_times, ke_values, 'b-', linewidth=2)
147        plt.xlabel('Time', fontsize=12)
148        plt.ylabel('Kinetic Energy', fontsize=12)
149        plt.title('Evolution of Kinetic Energy', fontsize=14)
150        plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
151        plt.tight_layout()
152        plt.savefig('kinetic_energy.png', dpi=150)
153        print("  Kinetic energy plot saved to 'kinetic_energy.png'")
154    
155    # Export to VTK for visualization in ParaView
156    print("\n  Exporting solutions to VTK format...")
157    
158    pvd_file = export_time_series(
159        mesh=mesh,
160        solutions=solutions,
161        times=times,
162        field_names=["velocity", "pressure"],
163        output_name="cavity_animation",
164        output_dir="vtk_output",
165        subdivision=2,
166        include_pressure=True,
167        verbose=True
168    )
169    
170    # Compute and display statistics at different times
171    from ngsolve import Integrate, sqrt, InnerProduct
172    
173    print("\n  Velocity statistics at selected times:")
174    print(f"  {'Time':>8s} | {'Max |u|':>10s} | {'Avg |u|':>10s}")
175    print("  " + "-"*35)
176    
177    for i, (t, sol) in enumerate(zip(times, solutions)):
178        if i % max(1, len(times)//5) == 0:  # Show ~5 snapshots
179            velocity = sol.components[0]
180            velocity_magnitude = sqrt(InnerProduct(velocity, velocity))
181            
182            # Note: max velocity computation needs evaluation at points
183            avg_velocity = Integrate(velocity_magnitude, mesh) / Integrate(1, mesh)
184            
185            print(f"  {t:8.4f} | {'--':>10s} | {avg_velocity:10.6f}")
186    
187    # Final summary
188    print("\n" + "="*70)
189    print("SIMULATION COMPLETE")
190    print("="*70)
191    print(f"✓ Computed {len(solutions)} time snapshots")
192    print(f"✓ Final time reached: {times[-1]:.4f}")
193    print(f"✓ Solutions exported to VTK format")
194    print(f"✓ View results in ParaView: paraview unsteady_cavity.vtu")
195    print("="*70)
196
197
198if __name__ == "__main__":
199    main()
